question: Let us c onsider the following subalgorithm, with the input parameter the natural number n and that returns a natural number. Subalgorithm compute(n): E â† 1 P â† 1 i â† 2 While i â‰¤ n do P â† (-1) * P * i E â† E + P i â† i + 1 EndWhile return E EndSubalgorithm What is the value returned by the subalgorithm , considering that n â‰¥ 1?

An Excel file contains  n records, numbered from 1 to n. These records are copied into a Word file, where the records have to be arranged into r rows and c columns o n each page (excep t the first and the last page). The first page of the Word document has a header , therefore its number of rows is r1, r1 < r (the number of rows on the first page is smaller ). The records will be arranged into the Word file on each page starting from top to bottom on each column, the column s being filled in from left to right: if the first record on some page is numbered  i, then the record numbered  (i + 1) will be placed below it; the record numbered (i + r) will be th e first record on the column 2 on that page, and so on. Considering that n = 5000 , r = 46, r1 = 12 and c = 2, on what page and column of the Word document will the record having the order  number i = 3245  be placed ?

answers.A: Page 36, last column

answers.B: Page 37, first column

answers.C: Page 37, last column

answers.D: Page 38, first column

question: Let us consider the subalgorithm whatDoes ItDo(m), where  m is a natural number (10  â‰¤ m â‰¤ 10000). Subalgorithm whatDoesItDo (m): If m = 0 then return 0 EndIf If m MOD 9 = 0 then return 9 EndIf return m MOD 9 EndSubalgorithm 2 Which of the following statements are true?

answers.A: The subalgorithm returns the remainder of the division of number m by 9.

answers.B: The subalgorithm returns the number of divisors of number m that are divisible by  9.

answers.C:
The subalgorithm return s the control digit of number m (the sum of its digits, then the digit
sum of this sum, until the obtained sum is formed out of a single digit).

answers.D:
The subalgorithm returns the control digit of number m (the sum of its digits, then the digit
sum of this sum, until the obtained sum is formed out of a single digit) if and only if number
m is divisible by 9.

question: In order to generate the numbers with n digits composed only of the digits 0, 2, 9,  one uses an algorithm which, for n = 2, generates in increasing order the numbers 20, 22, 29, 90, 92, 99 . If n = 4 and the same algorithm is used, which number is generated immediately after 2009 ?

answers.D: None of the other choices

question: Let us consider the subalgorithm search(n) , where n is a natural number (0 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 1000000). Subalgorithm search(n): v â† 0 If n = 0 then return 1 else m â† n While m > 0 do If m MOD 10 = 0 then v â† v + 1 EndIf m â† m DIV 10 EndWhile return v EndIf EndSubalgorithm Which of the following statements are true?

answers.A: The subalgorithm computes and returns the number of digits of n.

answers.B: The subalgorithm returns 1 if n is a power of 10 and 0 otherwise.

answers.C: The subalgorithm returns 1 if nâ€™s last digit is 0 and 0 otherwise.

answers.D: The subalgorithm computes and returns the number of digits 0 of n.

question: Let us consider the subalgorithm abc(a, n, p) , where n is a natural number (1 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 10000), p is a whole  number ( -10000 â‰¤ p â‰¤ 10000) and a is an array of n non-zero natural numbers ( a[1], a[2], â€¦, a[n]). Subalgorithm  abc(a, n, p): If n < 1 then return 0 else If (1 â‰¤ p) AND (p â‰¤ n) then return a[p] else return -1 EndIf EndIf EndSubalgorithm  3 Which of the following statements are true?

answers.A: The subalgorithm returns -1 if and only if p is negative or greater than n.

answers.B:
The subalgorithm returns the element  at position p if p is strictly greater than 0 and less than
or equal to the arrayâ€™s length .

answers.C:
The subalgorithm never return s 0 for parameter values that meet the preconditions from the
statement.

answers.D:
The subalgorithm returns the element at position p if p is greater than or equal to 0 and strictly
smaller  than the arrayâ€™s length. In cas e p is not between 1 and n, the subalgorithm returns -1.

question: Which of the following sequences determines  in variable i the length of an array of characters that ends with character '*' (star)? The index of the first character is 1 and the star character is part of the character array.

answers.A:
i â† 1
While x[i] â‰  '*' do
i â† i + 1
EndWhile

answers.B:
i â† 1
While x[i] = '*' do
i â† i + 1
EndWhile
i â† i - 1

answers.C:
i â† 1

i â† i + 1
EndWhile
i â† i + 1

answers.D:

While x[i] â‰  '*' do
i â† i + 1

question: Let us consider the following subalgorithm, with the input parameter the non -zero natural number n and which return s a natural number. Subalgorithm f(n): j â† n While j > 1 do i â† 1 While i â‰¤ n do i â† 2 * i EndWhile j â† j DIV 3 EndWhile return j EndSubalgorithm To which of the following complexity classes does the time complexity of the subalgorithm belong ?

answers.A: O(log 2 ğ’)

answers.B: O(log 22 ğ’)

answers.C: O(log 32 ğ’)

answers.D: O(log 2 log 3 n) 4

question: The subalgorithm  howMany(n, m) has as input parameters the natural numbers n and m. Subalgorithm howMany(n, m): If n â‰¤ m then If (n MOD 2 = 0) AND (n MOD 3 â‰  0) then return 1 + howMany(n + 1, m) else return howMany(n + 1, m) EndIf else return 0 EndIf EndSubalgorithm Which of the following statements are true?

answers.A: If n = 0 and m = 1, the subalgorithm returns the value 0.

answers.B: If n = 4 and m = 21, the subalgorithm returns the value 6.

answers.C: If n = 7 and m = 120, the subalgorithm returns the value 36.

answers.D: If n = 1 and m = 215, the subalgorithm returns the value 72.

question: Let us consider the subalgorithm verify(n) , where n is a natural number (1 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 100000). Subalgorithm verify(n): While n > 0 do If (n MOD 3) > 1 then return 0 EndIf n â† n DIV 3 EndWhile return 1 EndSubalgorithm Which of the following statements are true?

answers.A: The subalgorithm returns 1 if n is a power of 3 and 0, otherwise.

answers.B:
The subalgorithm returns 1 if nâ€™s representation  in base 3 contains  only the digits 0 and/or 1;
0, otherwise.

answers.C: The subalgorithm returns 1 if n can be written as a sum of distinct powers of 3 ; 0, otherwise.

answers.D:
The subalgorithm returns 1 if nâ€™s representation in base  3 contains only the digit 2; 0,
otherwise.

question: For a natural number nr (1000 â‰¤ nr â‰¤ 1000000), the decrementation operation is defined as follows: if the last digit of nr is not 0, then we subtract 1 from nr, otherwise, we divide nr by 10 and keep the integer part of it. Which of the following  subalgorithms , when calling decrement(nr, k) , returns  the number obtained by applying  the decrementation operation  k times (0 â‰¤ k â‰¤ 100) on number nr? For example, for nr = 15243 and k = 10, the result is 151.

answers.A:
Subalgorithm  decrement(nr, k):
If k = 0 then
return nr
else
If nr MOD 10 â‰  0 then
return decrement(nr DIV 10, k - 1)
else
return decrement(nr - 1, k - 1)
EndIf
EndIf
EndSubalgorithm
5

answers.B:
Subalgorithm  decrement(nr, k):
While k > 0 do
If nr MOD 10 = 0 then
nr â† nr DIV 10
else
nr â† nr - 1
EndIf
EndWhile
return nr
EndSubalgorithm

answers.C:
Subalgorithm  decrement(nr, k):
For i â† 1, k do
If nr MOD 10 > 0 then
nr â† nr - 1
else
nr â† nr DIV 10
EndIf
EndFor
return nr
EndSubalgorithm

answers.D:
Subalgorithm  decrement(nr, k):
If k = 0 then
return nr
else
If k > nr MOD 10 then
nr1 â† nr DIV 10
return decrement(nr1,   k - nr MOD 10 - 1)
else
return decrement(nr - k, 0)
EndIf
EndIf
EndSubalgorithm

question: Let us consider the following subalgorithm, with the input par ameters the array x with n natural numbers ( x[1], x[2], â€¦, x[n]) and the whole  number n. Subalgorithm  f(x, n): If n = 1 then return 100 else If x[n] > f(x, n - 1) then return x[n] else return f(x, n - 1) EndIf EndIf EndSubalgorithm What is the result of executing the subalgorithm for x = [101, 7, 6, 3] and n = 4?

The following subalgorithm has as input param eters the array a with n natural numbers ( a[1], a[2], â€¦, a[n]) and the natural number n (2 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 10000). Subalgorithm  h(a, n): If n â‰¤ 0 then return 0 EndIf If (n MOD 2 = 0) AND (a[n] MOD 2 = 0) then return h(a, n - 1) + a[n] EndIf return h(a, n - 1) - a[n] EndSubalgorithm Which of the following statements are true ?

answers.A:
The subalgorithm  returns the difference between the sum of elements having the same parity
as their position and the sum of elements having different parity than their position in array a.

answers.B:
The subalgorithm returns the difference between the sum of even elements on even positions
and the sum of odd elements on odd positions of array a.

answers.C:
The subalgorithm returns the difference between the sum of the even elements and the sum of
the odd elements of array a.

answers.D:
The subalgorithm returns the difference between the sum of the even elements from even
positions and the sum of the other elements of array a.

question: Let us consider the subalgorithm whatDoesItDo(n) , with the param eter n a non-zero natural number. Subalgorithm whatDoesItDo (n): i â† 1 While n > 0 do If n MOD 2 â‰  0 then write i EndIf i â† i + 1 n â† n DIV 2 EndWhile EndSubalgorithm Which of the following statements are true?

answers.A: The subalgorithm prints the sequence: 12345 for n = 31.

answers.B: The subalgorithm prints the sequence: 234 for n = 14.

answers.C: The subalgorithm prints 1 in the beginning of the se quence, when  n is an odd number.

answers.D: The subalgorithm prints a single number for n = 2k, where k is a natural number.

question: Let us consider the set S, consisting of n intervals described by the lower boundary li and the upper boundary ui (li < ui âˆ€ i = 1... n). The subset Sâ€™ âŠ† S, consisting of m elements is built such that there are no two intervals in Sâ€™ that intersect one with another and m has the highest possible value. Which of the following strategies provide a correct solution for the problem?

answers.A:
The intervals from set S are ordered in ascen ding order based on their lower boundary. The
first interval from the ordered array of intervals is added to Sâ€™. The ordered array is navigated
following the sorted order and if an interval that do es not intersect with the last interval added
to Sâ€™ is found, then it will be added to Sâ€™.

answers.B:
The intervals from set S are ordered in ascending order based on their upper boundary. The
first interval from the ordered array of intervals is added to Sâ€™. The order ed array is navigated
following  the sorted order  and if an interval that do es not intersect with the last interval added
to Sâ€™ is found, then it will be added to Sâ€™.  7

answers.C:
The intervals from set S are ordered in ascending order based on their length. The first
interval from the ordered array of intervals is added to Sâ€™. The ordered array is navigated
following the sorted order and if an interval that do es not intersect with the last interval added
to Sâ€™ is found, then it will be added to Sâ€™.

answers.D:
The intervals from set S are ordered in ascending order based on the number of intervals from
S they intersect with . The first interval from the ordered array of intervals is added to Sâ€™. The
ordered array is navigated following the sorted order and if an interval that do es not intersect
with the last interval added to Sâ€™ is found, then it will be added to Sâ€™.

question: Let us consider the subalgorithm f(a, b) , with the input parameters two natural numbers a and b (1 â‰¤ a < b â‰¤ 1000). Subalgorithm  f(a, b): m â† 0 For n â† a, b do c â† 0 For d â† 1, n do If n MOD d = 0 then c â† c + 1 EndIf EndFor If c > m then m â† c EndIf EndFor For n â† a, b do c â† 0 For d â† 1, n do If n MOD d = 0 then c â† c + 1 EndIf EndFor If c = m then write n EndIf EndFor EndSubalgorithm Which of the following statements are true?

answers.A:
The subalgorithm prints the maximum between the number of divisors of a and the number of
divisors of b.

answers.B:
The subalgorithm prints the natural numbers from interval [ a, b] that have the greatest number
of divisors.

answers.C: The subalgorithm prints the number of divis ors for each natural number from interval [ a, b].

answers.D:
The subalgorithm prints the natural numbers from interval [ a, b] that have the greatest number
of proper divisors.

question: Let us consider the natural numbers a and b, where b â‰  0. Which of the following alternatives comput es: â€¢ a DIV b, if a MOD b = 0 â€¢ (a / b)  rounded up to the next whole number, if a MOD b â‰  0

answers.A: (a - 1) DIV b

answers.B: (a + b + 1) DIV b

answers.C: (a + b - 1) DIV b

question: Johnny has to implement the binary search algorithm of an element a in an array V of n (1 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 1000) whole numbers sorted in ascending order ( V[1], V[2], â€¦, V[n]). He writes the following subalgorithm : Subalgorithm BinarySearch(a, n, V): st â† 1 dr â† n While dr â€“ st > 1 execute m â† (st + dr) DIV 2 If a â‰¤ V[m] then dr â† m else st â† m EndIf EndWhile return dr EndSubalgorithm Which of the following statements are true?

answers.A: If n = 1 then the value returned by the subalgorithm is always 1.

answers.B:
For any n â‰¥ 1, the subalgorithm written by Johnny returns the value 1 when a is smaller than
all the elements of the array.

answers.C:
When the element a exists in the array, the subalgorithm written by Johnny DOES NOT
always return the position (index from array V) at which the element  is located.

answers.D:
For any n > 1, the subalgorithm written by Johnny returns the value n when a is greater than
all the elements of the array.

question: Let us consider the subalgorithm compute(x, n) , where the input param eters are the natural numbers n and x, where 1 â‰¤ x â‰¤ n < 10. Subalgorithm compute(x, n): b â† 1 For i â† 1, n - x do b â† b * i EndFor a â† b For i â† n â€“ x + 1, n do a â† a * i EndFor return a DIV b EndSubalgorithm Which of the following statements are true?

answers.B: If n = 3 and x = 2, then the subalgorithm returns 6.

The subalgorithm returns the cardinal number of the set { ğ‘1ğ‘2â€¦ğ‘ğ‘¥  : ci â‰  cj âˆ€ 1 â‰¤ i, j â‰¤ x, i â‰  j,
1 â‰¤ ci â‰¤ n}

answers.D: The subalgorithm executes n multiplication operations.

question: Let us consider subalgorithm what(n,k) , which receives as parameters two non -zero natural numbers n and k (1 â‰¤ n, k â‰¤ 1000000). 9 Subalgorithm what(n, k): While n â‰¥ 1 execute If k â‰¤ n then i â† k else i â† n EndIf n â† n - i x â† 1 While i â‰¥ 1 execute Write x,â€™ â€™ x â† x + 1 i â† i - 1 EndWhile EndWhile EndSubalgorithm Which of the following statements are true?

answers.A: For n = 8 and k = 3 the subalgorithm prints the array 1 2 3 1 2 3 1 2

answers.B: For k = 2, the smallest value of n for which the value 1 is printed 3 times is n = 3.

answers.C: For k = 5, the smallest value of n for which the value 2 is printed 37 times is n = 182 .

answers.D: For n = 7 and k = 3 the subalgorithm prints 1 2 3 1 2 3

question: Let us consider the subalgorithm compute(a, b, c) , with input parameters non -zero natural numbers, that computes the greatest common divisor of the three given numbers. Which of the following implementations  for the subalgorithm  are correct?

answers.A:
Subalgorithm  compute(a, b, c):
While (a â‰  b) OR (a â‰  c) OR (b â‰  c) do
x â† a
If a â‰  x then
a â† a - x
EndIf
If b â‰  x then
b â† b - x
EndIf
If c â‰  x then
c â† c - x
EndIf
EndWhile
return x
EndSubalgorithm

answers.B:
Subalgorithm  compute(a, b, c):
x â† a
y â† b
While x â‰  y do
If x > y then
x â† x - y
else
y â† y - x
EndIf
EndWhile
z â† c
While x â‰  z do
If x > z then
x â† x - z
else
z â† z - x
EndIf
EndWhile
return x
EndSubalgorithm  10

answers.C:
Subalgorithm  compute(a, b, c):
While (a â‰  b) OR (a â‰  c) OR (b â‰  c) do
x â† a
If b < x then
x â† b
EndIf
If c < x then
x â† c
EndIf
If a â‰  x then
a â† a - x
EndIf
If b â‰  x then
b â† b - x
EndIf
If c â‰  x then
c â† c - x
EndIf
EndWhile
return x
EndSubalgorithm

answers.D:
Subalgorithm  compute(a, b, c):
x â† a
y â† b
r â† x MOD y
While r â‰  0 do
x â† y
y â† r
r â† x MOD y
EndWhile
z â† c
r â† y MOD z
While r â‰  0 do
y â† z
z â† r
r â† y MOD z
EndWhile
return z
EndSubalgorithm

question: The subalgorithm whatDoesItDo(n)  has as input parameter the natural number n (1 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 100). Subalgorithm  whatDoesItDo (n): s â† 0 If n MOD 2 = 0 then a â† 1 While a < n do s â† s + a a â† a + 2 EndWhile else b â† 2 While b < n do s â† s + b b â† b + 2 EndWhile EndIf return s EndSubalgorithm  11 Which of the  following statements are true?

answers.A:
If n is even, the subalgorithm returns the sum of the natural numbers strictly smaller than n; if
n is odd, it returns the sum of the even natural numbers smaller than n.

answers.B:
If n is even, the subalgorithm  returns the sum of the even natural numbers strictly smaller
than n; if n is odd, it returns the sum of the odd natural numbers smaller than n.

answers.C:
If n is even, the subalgorithm returns the sum of the odd natural numbers smaller than n; if n
is odd, it returns the sum of the even natural numbers smaller than n.

answers.D:
If n is even, the subalgorithm returns the sum of the even natural numbers strictly smaller
than n; if n is odd, it returns the sum of the natural numbers strictly smaller than n.

question: The subalgorithm whatDoesItDo(a)  has the input parameter the natural number a (1 â‰¤ a â‰¤ 100000). Subalgorithm whatDoesItDo (a): b â† 0 c â† 0 d â† 0 e â† 1 While a > 0 do d â† a MOD 10 If (d â‰  4) AND (d < 7) then b â† b + e * (d DIV 2) c â† c + e * (d - d DIV 2) else b â† b + e c â† c + e * (d - 1) EndIf a â† a DIV 10 e â† e * 10 EndWhile write b write c EndSubalgorithm Which of the following pair s of values will never be printed for any valid input  values ?

Let us consider the subalgorithms f(n, c)  and g(n, c) , having the input parame ters the natural numbers n and c. Subalgorithm f(n, c): If n â‰¤ 9 then If n = c then return 1 else return 0 EndIf else If n MOD 10 = c then return f(n DIV 10, c) + 1 else return f(n DIV 10, c) EndIf EndIf EndSubalgorithm  12 Subalgorithm g(n, c): If c = 0 then return 0 else If f(n, c) > 0 then return g(n, c - 1) + 1 else return g(n, c - 1) EndIf EndIf EndSubalgorithm What is the result of the call g(n, 9) ?

answers.A: It returns the number of digits of number n.

answers.B: It returns the number of distinct digits of number n.

answers.C: It returns the number of digits greater than 1 of number n.

answers.D: None of the other  answer s are correct.

question: On a site each registered user has a secret code of n digits instead of a password. For logging i n, the user does not have to introduce the entire code, instead the site randomly generates 3 distinct positions  p1, p2 and p3, such that 1 â‰¤ p1 < p2 < p3 â‰¤ n and the user only has to introduce the digits from those positions. For example, if the userâ€™s co de is 987654321 and the site randomly generates the positions 2, 5 and 7, the user has to introduce the digits 8, 5, 3. Below, the values introduced by a user for 9 logins are given. 1, 2, 3 2, 9, 0 6, 3, 2 2, 0, 2 1, 4, 7 9, 3, 2 4, 4, 3 4, 3, 1 5, 6, 0 Assuming that all 9 logins are valid and the user code was not changed in the meantime, which of the below statements are correct.

answers.A: The user code surely does not contain the digit 8.

answers.B: The shortest possible code has 12 digits.

answers.C: The shortest possible code contains the digit 2 at least 3 times.

answers.D: The sum of the digits in the shortest possible code may be 44.

question: Let us consider the subalgorithm  f(x, n)  where x, n are natural numbers and x > 0. Subalgorithm  f(x, n): If n = 0 then return 1 EndIf m â† n DIV 2 p â† f(x, m) If n MOD 2 = 0 then return p * p EndIf return x * p * p EndSubalgorithm Which of the following statements are true?

answers.A: The subalgorithm returns xn.

answers.B: If we replace â€œn MOD 2â€ with â€œm MOD 2â€ then the subalgorithm will return xn.

answers.C: The statements after the recursive call will never be executed.

answers.D: The subalgorithm returns xn if and only if n is even.  13

question: Let us consider the subalgorithm f2(a,b)  with the input parameters a and b natural numbers and the subalgorithm f(arr, i, n, p)  with the input parameters the array arr with n whole numbers (arr[1], arr[2], â€¦, arr[n]), and the whole numbers i and p. Subalgorithm  f2(a, b): If a > b then return a else return b EndIf EndSubalgorithm Subalgorithm  f(arr, i, n, p): If i = n then return 0 EndIf n1 â† f(arr, i + 1, n, p) n2 â† 0 If p + 1 â‰  i then n2 â† f(arr, i + 1, n, i) + arr[i] EndIf return f2(n1, n2) EndSubalgorithm State the result of the call f(arr, 1, 9, -10), if array arr consists of the values (10, 1, 3, 4, 8, 12, 1, 11, 6).

Let us consider the subalgorithm verify(n) , with  the input parameter a whole number n (1 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 100000) that return s true if n contains a digit that is equal to the sum of the other digits. For example, verify(1517)  returns true because 7 = 1 + 5 + 1. Which of the following alternatives represent correct implementations of the verify(n) subalgorithm?

answers.A:
Subalgorithm  verify(n):
s â† 0
c â† n
r â† false
While c > 0 do
s â† s + c MOD 10
c â† c DIV 10
EndWhile
c â† n
While c > 0 do
d â† c MOD 10
If d = s - d then
r â† true
else
r â† false
EndIf
c â† c DIV 10
EndWhile
return r
EndSubalgorithm
14

answers.B:
Subalgorithm  verify(n):
m â† -1
c â† n
r â† false
While c > 0 do
d â† c MOD 10
c â† c DIV 10
If d > m then
m â† d
EndIf
EndWhile
c â† n
s â† 0
While c > 0 do
d â† c MOD 10
If d â‰  m then
s â† s + d
EndIf
c â† c DIV 10
EndWhile
If s = m then
r â† true
EndIf
return r
EndSubalgorithm

answers.C:
Subalgorithm  verify(n):
v â† [0,0,0,0,0,0,0,0,0]
r â† false
While n > 0 do
d â† n MOD 10
If d > 0 then
v[d] â† v[d] + 1
EndIf
n â† n DIV 10
EndWhile
m â† 9
While v[m] = 0 do
m â† m - 1
EndWhile
If v[m] = 1 then
d â† m
s â† 0
m â† m - 1
While m > 0 do
s â† s + v[m] * m
m â† m - 1
EndWhile
If d = s then
r â† true
EndIf
EndIf
return r
EndSubalgorithm

answers.D:
None of the other  answer s are correct.



15

question: Let us consider the subalgorithm f(x, n, e, y, m) , with the input parameters an array x with n elements  that are whole numbers ( x[1], x[2], â€¦, x[n]), an array  y with m elements that are  whole numbers ( y[1], y[2], â€¦, y[m]), and a whole number e that does not appear  in the array y. The subalgorithm returns an array and a natural number. Consider the following subalgorithms as well: â€¢ (c, p) â† concatenate(a, n, b, m)  that has the input param eters an array a with n elements that are  whole numbers and an array b with m elements that are  whole numbers, and returns the array c with p elements that are whole numbers , representing the concatenation of the arrays a and b, namely: a[1], a[2], â€¦, a[n], b[1], b[2], â€¦, b[m] â€¢ (c, p) â† difference(a, n, b, m) that has the input parameters an array a with n elements that are  whole numbers and an array b with m elements that are  whole numbers,  and returns the array c with p elements that are whole numbers , consist ing of all elements of array a (the remaining elements keeping  their initial ordering) that do not  appear in array b

Subalgorithm  f(x, n, e, y, m): 2.     If n = 0 then 3.         return [], 0 4.     EndIf 5.     If x[1] â‰  e then 6.         s â† [] 7.         s[1] â† x[1] 8.         (r1, l1) â† difference(x, n, s, 1) 9.         (r2, l2) â† f(r1, l1, e, y, m) 10.         (r3, l3) â† concatenate(s, 1, r2, l2) 11.         return r3, l3 12.     else 13.         (r1, l1) â† f(y, m, e, x, n) 14.         s â† [] 15.         s[1] â† x[1] 16.         (r2, l2) â† difference(x, n, s, 1) 17.         (r3, l3) â† f(r2, l2 , e, y, m) 18.         (r4, l4) â† concatenate(r1, l1, r3, l3) 19.         return r4, l4 20.     EndIf
EndSubalgorithm Which of the following statements are true?

answers.A:
The subalgorithm f(x, n, e, y, m)  builds a one dimensional array starting from the array x
in which the occurences of element e are removed and replaced with the elements of array y at
each occurence of element e. The subalgorithm  returns the built array and its dimension.

answers.B:
If arrays x and y do not have common elements, then the array returned by the subalgorithm
f(x, n, e, y, m)  will consist of distinct elements only.

answers.C:
The length of the array returned by the subalgorithm f(x, n, e, y, m), having input
parameters the non -empty arrays x and y, can be smaller than n.

answers.D:
If on line 18, instead of r1 and l1 we had y and m then the function would return a one
dimensional array (together with its dimension) that would start with the elements of array y,
followed by the elements of array x, the occurences of e being replaced by the elements of
array y.

question: Let us consider the subalgorithm s(a, b, c) , where a, b, c are non-zero natural  numbers and b â‰¥ a. Subalgorithm s(a, b, c): If c = 0 then return 1 else If a > b then return (1 / a) * s(a - 1, b, c) else If a < b then return (1 / b) * s(a, b - 1, c) else return c * s(a - 1, b - 1, c - 1) EndIf EndIf EndIf EndSubalgorithm What should be the relation between a, b and c in order to obtain 1/ Cba (where Cba represents combinations of b taken a at a time ).

answers.A: a + b = c

answers.B: a + c = b

answers.C: b - c = a

answers.D: b + c = a - b
